lines.content: Dyuque is a desktop task manager chatbot built with JavaFX. It supports todos, deadlines, and events, with persistent local storage.
1. Open IntelliJ. If a project is already open, go to `File` → `Close Project` to return to the welcome screen.
2. Click `Open`, select the project directory, and click `OK`. Accept any further defaults.
3. Configure the project to use **JDK 17**: [IntelliJ SDK setup guide](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk). Set **Project language level** to `SDK default`.
4. To run the app, locate `src/main/java/dyuque/Launcher.java`, right-click it, and choose `Run Launcher.main()`.
> **Note:** Do not rename or move the `src/main/java` folder — Gradle expects Java sources to be at this path.
The project uses **Gradle** with the Shadow plugin to produce a fat jar.
Use the wrapper scripts (`gradlew` on Unix/macOS, `gradlew.bat` on Windows), no local Gradle installation is required.
The output jar will be at `build/libs/dyuque.jar`. Run it with:
Tests are written with **JUnit 5** and cover command parsing and execution logic.
Test results are printed to the console.
Checkstyle is configured using the rules in `config/checkstyle/`.
with modifications to switch-case indentations, namely setting `case` indentations from `0` to `4`:
<property name="caseIndent" value="4" />  <!-- for Lambda-style. Suppress traditional cases manually -->
This was done because (from my understanding) Checkstyle cannot differentiate between traditional and lambda-style
switch-case statements when it comes to indentation, as requested in the
Some classes also have inline suppressions, notably single-line lambda expressions.
│   │   ├── Dyuque.java          # Core chatbot logic and command dispatch
│   │   ├── Parser.java          # Parses raw input into commands
│   │   ├── Deadline.java        # Task with a due date
│   │   ├── Event.java           # Task with a date range
## Code Reuse Credits and AI declaration
* Claude was used to generate chat bubble "profile pictures".
* AI was used for a large portion of generating Javadocs to help me learn best practices and save time.
* AI was used extensively in certain classes like Parser, Storage, and JavaFX classes.
* AI was also used in general for refining my high-level design plans and troubleshooting.
* Reused code blocks are tagged with `@@author wesley-pribadi-reused`.

Dyuque is a **desktop task manager chatbot** for keeping track of todos, deadlines, and events. Interact with it through a simple text-based chat interface.
1. Ensure you have **Java 17** or later installed.
3. Open a terminal in the folder containing the jar and run:
4. Type a command and press **Enter** to interact with Dyuque.
5. Refer to the [Command Summary](#command-summary) below for all available commands.
> **Save file:** Dyuque automatically saves your tasks to `dyuque_data/dyuque.txt` in the same directory as the jar. Tasks are loaded automatically on the next startup.
Adds a task with no associated date.
Adds a task with a due date.
Adds a task occurring over a date range.
> Dates must be in **ISO-8601 format**: `YYYY-MM-DD`. The end date cannot be before the start date.
Permanently removes the task at the given index. Use `list` to find a task's index.
Marks the task at the given index as completed.
Nice! I've marked this task as done:
Marks the task at the given index as not yet completed.
OK, I've marked this task as not done yet:

Reverses the most recent command that changed task data. This covers all commands from [Managing Tasks](#managing-tasks) and [Changing Task State](#changing-task-state). `undo` can be used multiple times to step back through the history one action at a time.
> **Note:** Undo history is not persisted — it resets when Dyuque is restarted.
If there is nothing left to undo:
Shows all tasks currently stored, with their index numbers and completion status.
Searches for tasks whose description contains the given keyword.
Displays the list of available commands and their syntax.
Saves all tasks and exits the application.
Goodbye, hope to see you again soon!

* Utility class for displaying application-level dialog windows.

*

This class provides helper methods for showing modal dialogs
* such as fatal error notifications. It centralizes dialog creation
* logic to avoid duplication across different UI controllers.

*

All dialogs created by this class are blocking and must be
* invoked on the JavaFX Application Thread.
* Displays a modal, resizable fatal error dialog and terminates the application.

*

The dialog contains the specified title, header text, and message body.
* It blocks user interaction with the application until dismissed.
* After the user closes the dialog, {@link javafx.application.Platform#exit()}
* is invoked to terminate the application.
* @param message The detailed error message to display.
alert.setHeaderText("Dyuque encountered a fatal error and needs to quit");
private static void throwDialog(String message, Alert alert) {
